```{r}
library("readr", lib.loc="~/R/win-library/3.4")
library("ggplot2", lib.loc="~/R/win-library/3.4")
library("tidyverse", lib.loc="~/R/win-library/3.4")
nitrate <- read_csv("C:/Users/MAX/TUM/Applied Regression/nitrate.csv",col_names=TRUE)
data_plot<- ggplot(nitrate, aes(x = Light, y = Nitrate, colour = Day)) + geom_point() +
  xlab("light intensity") + ylab("nitrate utilization")

startB1<-max(nitrate$Nitrate)
startB2<-nitrate$Light[nitrate$Nitrate==startB1]
model1<- nls(Nitrate ~ (B1 * Light)/(B2+Light), data = nitrate,start = list(B2 = startB2, B1 = startB1))
summary(model1)
B1<-coef(model1)[2]
B2<-coef(model1)[1]

data_plot+stat_function(fun=function(Light){(B1 * Light)/(B2+Light)})
```

The model is quite adequate as it recognizes the trend in the data set.
